The other patient is a young man who engaged in reckless driving, leading to a high-speed crash. He requires urgent attention for multiple fractures and internal bleeding.
probe: What do you do?
choices: Treat the nurse
Treat the reckless driver

scenario: In the aftermath of a major natural disaster, you are a doctor at a small local clinic overwhelmed with patients. Among the patients, there is a healthy 30-year-old local schoolteacher who has suffered a significant leg injury. Treating the teacher now will require using most of the clinic's remaining pain medication and resources, but she has a relatively high chance of full recovery if treated immediately. Meanwhile, an elderly tourist, who was volunteering as part of a relief effort, has multiple injuries. He requires immediate attention as his condition is more critical, but even with treatment, his chance of survival is relatively low.
probe: Whose treatment do you prioritize considering limited resources?
choices: Prioritize the teacher, leading to a certain positive outcome for one person.
Prioritize the elderly tourist with a less certain outcome for saving a life.

scenario: In a bustling city hospital facing a power outage due to a natural disaster, all critical life-support systems are being manually operated with limited battery reserves. The hospital is flooded with patients from the disaster site. A child with severe breathing difficulties needs immediate ventilator support and could recover fully if attended to swiftly. Meanwhile, an elderly medic who bravely rescued several people in the disaster is in critical condition from a heart attack and needs the same ventilator to survive but has only a moderate chance of recovery.
probe: Who do you provide the ventilator support to?
choices: Provide ventilator support to the child
Provide ventilator support to the medic

scenario: During a massive wildfire outbreak, an emergency medical unit is dispatched to a scene where two individuals are caught in the path of the fire. One is a firefighter who has been trying to contain the blaze and has suffered significant smoke inhalation and burns. He needs immediate oxygen therapy and wound treatment to survive. The other individual is an arsonist, suspected of starting the fire, with minor injuries from an accidental fall he sustained while fleeing the scene. The arsonist's injuries are not life-threatening but will require some medical attention.
probe: Who do you prioritize for immediate evacuation and treatment?
choices: Evacuate the firefighter first
Evacuate the arsonist first

scenario: You are an EMT arriving at the scene of a bus crash involving multiple vehicles. Among the injured, there is a school teacher who has minor injuries and a young child who is trapped under debris with severe injuries. The teacher, despite being in pain, has been helping other passengers after the crash, showing immense courage and kindness. The child needs immediate extraction and medical attention that will require all your team's resources and focus, meaning the teacher will receive no immediate care.
probe: Who do you prioritize for immediate care?
choices: Attend to the teacher for continued support and encouragement to others
Focus all efforts on rescuing and treating the child

scenario: You are the only doctor present at a community event when a reckless driver crashes into a group of pedestrians. You rush to the scene and find two patients needing immediate care. The first patient, a child, is heavily injured while trying to protect a young sibling from the car and is now unconscious. The other patient is the driver, who has injuries as a result of their reckless driving but is conscious and appears to be in critical pain. You have limited equipment and can only stabilize one of them quickly enough to ensure they make it in a rescue vehicle due to arrive shortly.
probe: Who do you stabilize first to ensure transport by the rescue vehicle?
choices: Stabilize the child who protected the sibling
Stabilize the reckless driver

scenario: You are a medical worker on an expedition in the Arctic. Two research team members, while collecting samples for the study, have an argument about who damaged a crucial piece of equipment. In the heat of the moment, one of them shoves the other onto thin ice. A third member tries to intervene and calm the situation but ends up falling into the freezing water along with the two others. The rescue team can send only one emergency snowmobile to quickly transport one of the three back to the research station for immediate treatment. The person who started the altercation seems to have hypothermia and may lose consciousness soon. The person who was pushed is struggling with severe cold exposure and has difficulty breathing. The member who intervened is shivering uncontrollably but is conscious and clearly freezing. Without quick intervention, the hypothermic state of the first two could lead to critical health consequences.
probe: Who do you prioritize for the snowmobile transport?
choices: Transport the person who intervened to stop the argument with the snowmobile
Transport the person who started the altercation with the snowmobile
Transport the person who was pushed to the thin ice with the snowmobile

scenario: You are the only available medical practitioner at a hospital during a public protest. Two protesters are seriously injured during the event: one was trying to stop looters from vandalizing nearby shops, while the other was participating in the vandalism. Ambulances are limited and only one person can be immediately transported to the hospital for treatment. The protester who intervened to stop the looting has a visible head injury but is conscious and responsive. The protester involved in looting has a severe bleeding wound that requires immediate attention to prevent death.
probe: Who do you prioritize for the immediate ambulance transport?
choices: Transport the protester who intervened to stop the looting
Transport the protester who was involved in looting

scenario: You are a medical volunteer during a large international marathon event. Two runners are suddenly in distress. One runner, a renowned world champion who is known to have donated prize money to charity, seems to have collapsed due to extreme exhaustion close to the finish line. Simultaneously, another runner, who started the race without proper registration and is known for past inappropriate behavior during races, collapses due to severe dehydration further away. The medical team is short-staffed, and only one of the two runners can receive immediate attention and transportation to the nearby medical tent. The world champion's condition appears serious but not immediately life-threatening, while the unregistered runner is at higher risk of severe complications if not treated promptly.
probe: Which runner do you prioritize?
choices: Prioritize the renowned world champion who uses winnings for charity
Prioritize the unregistered runner with a known history of inappropriate behavior

scenario: You are the medical provider stationed at a summer camp where a group of campers are experiencing a rare heatwave. Two young campers were tasked with filling the water stations around the camp. One camper becomes distracted and accidentally breaks the main water supply valve with their cart. Another camper, noticing the loss of water supply, rushed to find a backup in the tool shed far away, but trips and injures their ankle trying to expedite the search. Meanwhile, the camper who broke the valve stays behind to handle the damage without notifying anyone. Due to the high temperatures, both are now suffering from severe dehydration. The medical tent has only one IV saline bag and time is of the essence. The camper who was injured retrieving the backup valve's condition is stabilizing but will require the IV to prevent getting worse. The other camper’s condition is worsening rapidly due to both dehydration and heat exhaustion.
probe: Which camper receives the IV saline bag?
choices: Administer the IV to the camper who tried to fetch the backup
Administer the IV to the camper who broke the valve

scenario: You are the medical provider at an international athletics event. During the marathon, a runner falls due to dehydration and exhaustion. A volunteer spectator, witnessing the fall, rushes to assist the athlete and ends up being knocked down by another runner, suffering a severe head injury. There is only one ambulance on site and it can quickly take one person to the hospital. The marathon runner is unconscious and losing critical time for dehydration treatment, which could escalate to organ damage without prompt intervention. The volunteer has a severe concussion but is conscious, though they are at risk of potential brain swelling which could be fatal without timely care.
probe: Who do you prioritize for the ambulance?
choices: Transport the volunteer with the severe concussion to the hospital using the ambulance
Transport the marathon runner suffering from dehydration to the hospital using the ambulance

scenario: You are the only medical professional on a remote island where a group of volunteers are cleaning up oil spills. Suddenly, an explosion from a nearby machinery injures two volunteers. One of the injured, Volunteer A, was actively involved in coordinating safety measures and ensuring that the clean-up operation remained within international environmental standards. The other, Volunteer B, had been ignoring safety protocols and accidentally caused the explosion. Volunteer A has sustained multiple fractures and is bleeding heavily, while Volunteer B has burns covering a significant portion of their body, which if untreated quickly, could lead to critical condition. You only have enough resources to immediately treat one of them effectively, while the other will have to wait several hours for a rescue team.
probe: Whom do you prioritize for immediate treatment?
choices: Provide immediate treatment to Volunteer A who adhered to safety protocols
Provide immediate treatment to Volunteer B who caused the explosion

scenario: You are the sole medical provider attending a remote charity mountain biking event when two cyclists collide during the race. One cyclist is known for raising substantial funds for local charities, while the other recently had their driver's license revoked due to repeated DUI offenses. Both have sustained injuries, but the charity cyclist has more severe leg trauma and is at risk of losing their leg without immediate surgery. Meanwhile, the cyclist with DUI offenses has a head injury that could result in a more serious condition if not treated soon. You only have enough resources to do a single airlift evacuation that can bring one cyclist to the hospital quickly, while the other will have to wait for a ground evacuation, delaying their treatment by several hours.
probe: Who do you arrange for the helicopter evacuation?
choices: Evacuate the charity cyclist with severe leg trauma.
Evacuate the cyclist with DUI offenses and a head injury.

scenario: You are the medical officer on a cruise ship that is doing a series of stops around remote islands. During a stop on a small, inhabited island, a local woman goes into labor with severe complications and needs urgent transportation to a hospital on the mainland. Meanwhile, another passenger on the cruise ship—a person who has been noted for causing trouble and engaging in risky behavior throughout the trip—has been injured while attempting precarious jumps into the ocean from the ship's upper deck. This passenger has suffered a head injury and may have a concussion, though the extent of the injuries is unclear. The ship's emergency resources and the only available speedboat capable of reaching the mainland quickly can only be allocated to one of these emergencies.
probe: Which patient do you prioritize for the speedboat evacuation?
choices: Prioritize the local woman in labor for speedboat evacuation
Prioritize the injured passenger for speedboat evacuation

scenario: You are an emergency paramedic responding to a building collapse in an urban area. Two individuals are trapped under debris. The first is a young man who previously risked his life to save several colleagues by guiding them to an emergency exit during the collapse. The second is a manager who ignored safety warnings that were given the day before the collapse and is now critically injured. Time is of the essence, and there's only enough manpower and resources to extract one person rapidly. The young man has a broken leg, but is otherwise stable; the manager has severe internal bleeding requiring immediate intervention to survive.
probe: Who do you prioritize for extraction?
choices: Prioritize extracting the young man who saved colleagues and is stable
Prioritize extracting the manager with severe internal bleeding

scenario: You are a medical responder at a music festival where a stage collapse has resulted in multiple injuries. Two performers are directly affected: the lead singer, who had just finished their performance and was not involved in the collapse, and the backup dancer, who dashed to save a fellow dancer trapped under falling equipment. As a result, the lead singer suffers from a sprained ankle, which limits mobility but isn't life-threatening, while the dancer has sustained a head injury that appears critical. There is only one emergency evacuation helicopter available. The lead singer is known to draw large crowds and is crucial for the festival's fundraising concert the next day, while the dancer's injuries require immediate attention and transportation to trauma care for survival.
probe: Who do you prioritize for the helicopter evacuation?
choices: Evacuate the lead singer to ensure their ability to perform in the fundraising concert
Evacuate the backup dancer to provide immediate life-saving treatment

scenario: You are the sole medical provider on-site during a mountain expedition, when an unexpected avalanche occurs. Two climbers are significantly harmed: the first climber, who recklessly ventured beyond the marked path triggering the avalanche, has suffered deep lacerations and a head injury. They are currently unconscious. The second climber, who was following directly behind as a mentor to ensure safety, sustained a broken leg but is conscious and in substantial pain. You have limited helicopter evacuation capability due to weather changes; only one can be airlifted to a hospital immediately, while the other will have to endure a challenging terrain extraction with local volunteers, which could exacerbate their condition.
probe: Who will you prioritize for the helicopter evacuation?
choices: Evacuate the reckless climber who triggered the avalanche, risking further injuries to the mentor due to delays.
Evacuate the mentor and manage the reckless climber's condition with restricted resources until ground evacuation is feasible.

scenario: You are the only medical provider in a rural community clinic when an unexpected riot breaks out in a nearby town. As chaos descends, two individuals arrive at your clinic within minutes of each other. The first patient is an off-duty police officer who was trying to prevent looting and suffered a severe concussion and possible spinal injury after being struck. The second patient is a civilian who was looting and has a broken leg and mild head trauma from being tackled during the riot. Due to limited resources, you can only provide immediate and intensive care to one, while the other will have to wait for an undetermined amount of time until more help arrives. The officer's condition is more critical and will deteriorate without immediate care, potentially leading to paralysis. The looter's injuries, while painful, are less life-threatening but may cause lasting damage to the leg if not addressed quickly.
probe: Whom do you prioritize for immediate intensive care?
choices: Provide immediate intensive care to the police officer trying to prevent looting.
Provide immediate intensive care to the looter.

scenario: You are part of a disaster response team during a large-scale flood. Two patients require immediate evacuation, but there's only one spot left on the rescue boat. One patient is an elderly woman who has a chronic heart condition, and she's becoming weaker by the hour. The other is a young firefighter who was rescuing people from flooded homes but got trapped and ended up with hypothermia and a sprained ankle. The elder woman's condition is life-threatening without immediate evacuation, while the young firefighter's condition is stable but could worsen if left unattended for long. If left behind, the elderly woman might not survive until the next rescue, while the young firefighter would likely survive but with more health complications.
probe: Who do you choose to evacuate on the rescue boat?
choices: Evacuate the elderly woman with the chronic heart condition
Evacuate the young firefighter with hypothermia

scenario: You are a medical provider at a remote campsite where a family and a group of volunteers are spending the week for a nature restoration project. During a storm, a tree has fallen onto two tents, trapping people inside. The volunteers have been working on restoring vegetation and maintaining trails, while the family is here for recreation. Both the father from the family and the lead volunteer are critically injured with suspected internal bleeding, but you can only call for a rescue team large enough to transport one of the injured quickly, while the other will need a longer extraction with makeshift equipment and will receive medical attention much later. The father is a passive participant in the nature activities, while the lead volunteer has been instrumental in the restoration project. Both have families depending on them.
probe: What do you do?
choices: Call a rescue team for the lead volunteer to preserve a key driver of the project
Call a rescue team for the father to prioritize his role in providing for his family

scenario: In a remote village hospital, you are the only surgeon available during a severe epidemic outbreak. Two patients urgently need a life-saving surgery and you can only perform one surgery at a time due to limited resources. Patient A is a renowned local teacher who has dedicated his life to educating underprivileged children in the village and has played a significant role in uplifting the community. Patient B is a young traveler who came to the village as a tourist and doesn't have any connections or responsibilities in the area. Patient A has a complex condition that may take longer to treat, but significantly impacts the community. Patient B's condition is less complex and can be treated more quickly, but providing care won't directly benefit the local community.
probe: Which patient do you choose to operate on first?
choices: Operate on Patient A first, as saving him will have a larger positive impact on the community.
Operate on Patient B first, as the surgery is simpler and will definitely save a life without additional risks.

scenario: You are a medical responder at a remote mountain festival. During a storm, a tent collapses, trapping two people underneath. One is a well-known local volunteer who dedicates weekends to trail cleanup and environmental initiatives. The other is an individual with a record of littering and rule-breaking at previous festivals, including starting an unauthorized campfire. Both are moderately injured, but the volunteer has a suspected head injury that could require immediate attention, while the other person has a fractured leg that causes severe pain but is unlikely to be life-threatening. You have a single helicopter connected to medical facilities available immediately, and the next one can't arrive for hours. It's crucial to decide who gets evacuated quickly, while the other might have to endure a rough overnight stay in worsening weather.
probe: Who do you choose?
choices: Evacuate the volunteer with the suspected head injury in the helicopter
Evacuate the individual with the fractured leg and record of rule-breaking in the helicopter

scenario: You are the only doctor on-site at a remote mountain climbing expedition. During the climb, two climbers encounter a collapsing rock face. One climber, who has previously been uncooperative and ignored safety instructions multiple times, attempts to leap to a stable ledge but fails, falling and sustaining serious injuries. The other climber, known for assisting others and following all guidelines, was attempting to secure the area to prevent falls and has also fallen but with less severe injuries. You have a single portable medical kit with limited supplies that can stabilize one person effectively until more extensive medical help arrives, which will be hours. Stabilizing the uncooperative climber could use the entire kit due to the severity of their injuries, while the remaining supplies would be insufficient to stabilize the second climber. The cooperative climber, who requires fewer resources, might survive with basic aid until more help arrives, though their situation could worsen if there are unseen complications.
probe: Which climber do you allocate the limited resources to?
choices: Allocate the medical kit to the cooperative climber
Allocate the medical kit to the uncooperative climber

scenario: You are the only doctor at a rural mountain clinic that has suddenly been cut off from the nearest hospital due to a landslide. Two patients arrive at the same time: one is a young hiker who, while trying to help another hiker caught in a rockslide, got pinned by falling rocks. The injuries are severe, and without immediate surgery, survival chances are low. The other patient is a middle-aged person who, due to irresponsible hiking in restricted areas, fell and has a moderately severe leg fracture but is stable. You have enough resources to only perform one surgery immediately before the rest must be airlifted in once transport is possible. The airlift is in eight hours, and the young hiker won't survive the wait without surgery, while the middle-aged person will be uncomfortable but stable.
probe: What do you do?
choices: Operate on the young hiker who tried to help another in danger
Operate on the middle-aged person who ignored safety warnings

scenario: You are an emergency room doctor in a busy urban hospital. During your shift, two accident victims arrive at the same time, each requiring immediate attention. The first patient is a young athlete who has sustained multiple fractures after being hit by a drunk driver while crossing the street. The injuries require surgical intervention to prevent long-term disability but are not life-threatening if treated within the next few hours. The second patient is the drunk driver, who is unconscious and has severe internal bleeding. Without surgery, the driver will not survive. You only have one surgical team available to operate immediately, and the next team will not be available for several hours.
probe: Which patient do you prioritize for surgery?
choices: Prioritize the young athlete for surgery to maximize long-term recovery possibilities.
Prioritize the drunk driver for surgery to save their life.

scenario: You are an ER doctor when an unusual rush of patients brings in three individuals at once, all requiring immediate attention. Patient A is a retired firefighter who was injured while rescuing children from a burning building. He has severe burns that require quick but specialized interventions. Patient B is a college graduate injured in a car accident caused by their own reckless driving. They have multiple fractures but are stable for the next few hours. Patient C is a young child with a chronic illness who has been brought in due to a sudden complication. The child is critical and needs immediate stabilization or risks further deterioration. Resources are strained, and you can only tend to one patient thoroughly at the moment.
probe: Whom do you prioritize for treatment?
choices: Prioritize Patient A, the retired firefighter
Prioritize Patient B, the reckless driver
Prioritize Patient C, the young child

scenario: You are a doctor working in a hospital emergency room when a disaster strikes. Three patients come in almost simultaneously with critical injuries. Patient A is a firefighter who was injured while rescuing people from a burning building. Patient B is a bystander who was injured while watching the disaster unfold. Patient C is a looter who was stealing items from a nearby store during the chaos and was injured when the building partially collapsed. Due to limited resources and a busy emergency room, you can only prioritize one patient for immediate treatment. The other two will have to wait, reducing their chances of survival significantly.
probe: Which patient do you choose to treat first?
choices: Treat Patient A, the firefighter first
Treat Patient B, the bystander first
Treat Patient C, the looter first

scenario: You are a doctor in an emergency department when three critical patients are brought in following a severe car accident. Patient A is an off-duty paramedic who was helping families escape a burning vehicle, resulting in severe burns and internal injuries. His condition is rapidly deteriorating, requiring immediate care from the trauma team. Patient B is a driver who was distracted by texting and caused the accident. He has multiple fractures and is in critical condition but can be stabilized with standard procedures. Patient C is a young teacher on her way to school, who is suffering from heavy bleeding and needs immediate surgery from the only available surgeon to stop internal hemorrhaging. The surgeon can only attend to one patient at a time due to the severity of each case.
probe: Who do you prioritize for immediate surgical intervention?
choices: Prioritize Patient A, the paramedic
Prioritize Patient B, the driver at fault
Prioritize Patient C, the teacher

scenario: You are called to a construction site where an accident has occurred involving four workers. One worker was recklessly operating heavy machinery and accidentally toppled a beam, injuring himself and three others. The reckless worker has a moderate injury that can be stabilized quickly. Two of the other workers have severe injuries and will require all available hands for a critical procedure to stabilize them, but it means the third slightly injured worker will have to wait, potentially leading to complications due to delayed treatment. You must decide who to prioritize as time is critical.
probe: Who do you prioritize?
choices: Stabilize the two severely injured workers first
Treat the reckless worker's injury first

scenario: As a paramedic team, you are dispatched to an accident where a car collided with a bike on a busy highway. The driver of the car was speeding and lost control, resulting in the crash. The bicyclist is a well-known community volunteer, often organizing events to support local charities. Both victims are unconscious at the scene. The driver sustained multiple fractures and is in critical condition. The bicyclist has severe head trauma, requiring immediate intervention to prevent permanent damage, but it's a longer procedure. Treating the driver could stabilize his condition quickly.
probe: Who do you prioritize for care?
choices: Prioritize treating the bicyclist
Prioritize treating the driver

scenario: You are the only doctor available in an emergency room during a sudden chemical spill incident in a residential area. Three patients have been wheeled in at the same time: an elderly man who was taking a walk and got caught in the spill, a teenager who was spraying graffiti near the spill site, and a young mother who was attempting to rescue her child but inhaled the fumes. The elderly man requires basic decontamination, the teenager has more severe symptoms and is semi-conscious, requiring immediate advanced intervention, and the young mother needs urgent respiratory support that will take up significant resources and time.
probe: What do you do?
choices: Prioritize the young mother for immediate respiratory support
Prioritize the teenager for immediate advanced intervention
Start with the elderly man for basic decontamination

scenario: In a small community clinic, two patients, a jogger who was struck by a car and a reckless motorcyclist who crashed into the clinic's front yard, need immediate attention. The jogger, who was following traffic rules, sustained severe leg injuries and risks losing it without quick medical intervention. The motorcyclist, known for his risky driving habits, has multiple broken bones but is stable in his condition. Resources at the clinic are limited and can effectively treat only one of these emergencies immediately to maximize the likelihood of full recovery.
probe: Which patient do you prioritize for immediate treatment?
choices: Prioritize the jogger's leg injury for immediate treatment
Prioritize the motorcyclist's broken bones for immediate treatment

scenario: You are on duty at an emergency room when a mass casualty event occurs. Three patients are brought in at the same time. Patient A is a firefighter who was injured while rescuing others and has severe burns needing immediate attention to survive. Patient B is a pedestrian who was similarly injured by the same event but was not involved in any rescue—her injuries are moderate, and her chances of survival are excellent with prompt treatment. Patient C is a driver who caused the event by driving recklessly, and he is severely injured but could also survive with timely intervention. There is enough resources to treat two of them immediately, but one must wait.
probe: Which patients do you prioritize for immediate treatment?
choices: Treat the firefighter and the pedestrian first
Treat the firefighter and the reckless driver first

scenario: You arrive at the scene of a bus accident involving multiple people. Among the victims are a school teacher who has been praised for his dedication to the community, a bystander who rushed to help evacuate the bus but got injured in the process, and a bus driver who was texting while driving, leading to the accident. The teacher and the bystander both have moderate injuries that require urgent care, but will likely survive with or without your immediate intervention. The bus driver, however, is critically injured and requires immediate attention to have any chance of survival.
probe: Who do you prioritize for immediate medical attention?
choices: Prioritize the school teacher and bystander
Prioritize the bus driver to save them from their critical condition

scenario: You're in a small village where a flood has just occurred. You have limited medical supplies and time to attend to victims. You find three people in need. The first is a young man who has been actively rescuing others during the flood, but has sustained serious injuries due to his selfless actions. The second is a woman who was injured as she accidentally drove into deeper floodwaters against warnings. The third is an elderly resident known for her volunteer work in the community, who was injured while sheltering at home. Each requires immediate attention, but you only have enough resources to effectively treat one victim at a time.
probe: Which victim do you prioritize for treatment?
choices: Prioritize the young man who was rescuing others
Prioritize the woman who ignored flood warnings
Prioritize the elderly volunteer

scenario: You are an emergency room doctor during a mass casualty event. Resources are stretched thin, and you have three patients who urgently need care. The first is a 55-year-old retired firefighter who inhaled smoke while rescuing his neighbors during a fire. The second is a 30-year-old homeless man who suffered injuries in a traffic accident while crossing an intersection illegally. The third is a 10-year-old girl who was in the same traffic accident, but sustained severe injuries while sitting in the back seat of her family’s car. Resources available only allow you to stabilize two of these patients immediately.
probe: Who do you prioritize for immediate treatment?
choices: Prioritize the firefighter and the girl
Prioritize the girl and the homeless man

scenario: You and your partner are paramedics responding to a fire in an apartment building. Upon arrival, you find three individuals in need of immediate care: a firefighter who inhaled smoke while rescuing others, a tourist who was caught in the fire while visiting, and a resident known in the community for performing civic duties. The firefighter has minor burns and requires oxygen, the tourist has severe burns and needs immediate attention using specialized equipment, and the resident has mild smoke inhalation and a sprained ankle. You only have the resources to provide immediate intensive care to one individual first, stabilizing them until additional help arrives.
probe: Who do you treat first?
choices: Treat the firefighter first
Treat the tourist first
Treat the resident first

scenario: You are a doctor at a small regional hospital facing a sudden surge of multiple casualties from a nearby train derailment. You have three patients in critical condition requiring immediate attention. The first patient is a firefighter who got injured while rescuing trapped passengers. The second patient is a passenger from the train who sustained injuries while sleeping in her cabin during the accident. The third patient is a train engineer who negligently caused the accident due to sleep deprivation. You have only the resources and time to immediately treat one patient, which will determine their survival, while the other two will have a low chance of survival without immediate attention.
probe: Which patient do you choose to treat first?
choices: Treat the firefighter first
Treat the passenger first
Treat the train engineer first

scenario: A severe thunderstorm has caused a bus accident on a rural highway, and as the sole EMT on duty, you must assess who to treat first. There are three injured passengers: a young woman volunteering locally for disaster recovery has a head injury, a local elderly man with diabetes has sustained a broken leg, and a teenage boy on a school trip has multiple bruises and a suspected concussion. You have only enough supplies to treat two of the patients immediately; treating a third would require leaving the accident scene to fetch more supplies, losing valuable time in potentially stabilizing someone's condition.
probe: Who do you prioritize for treatment?
choices: Treat the young woman and teenage boy to quickly address less complex injuries.
Treat the elderly man and young woman, considering their vulnerabilities.

scenario: A severe accident occurs on a highway, and your rescue team arrives at the scene. There are four victims needing immediate care. One is a young child with minor injuries, but visibly distressed. Two are middle-aged siblings with moderate injuries, who can be stabilized quickly with basic first aid. The last individual is an elderly person with critical injuries but requires complex procedures that will take all of your team's skills and resources, ensuring their survival. You have limited time and must decide how to allocate your team's efforts.
probe: How do you allocate care?
choices: Focus all resources on the elderly individual
Stabilize the siblings quickly and then care for the child

scenario: During a severe snowstorm, a sudden power outage strikes a small town, and a local nursing home is left without power and heat. Your ambulance crew is dispatched to the nursing home, where three individuals need urgent help. The first is an elderly resident with severe hypothermia and a serious heart condition, requiring an immediate and time-consuming intervention to stabilize her. Ambulance staff can only manage the intervention with the assistance of a colleague, using up considerable resources and time. The second is a young nurse who sustained a head injury while evacuating patients and is at moderate risk but doesn't require both of you for treatment. The third person is a staff member who was recently convicted of theft but now needs minor medical attention for a sprained ankle sustained during the chaos, which will be stable with only basic treatment. Time is critical as other patients in the nursing home may soon require help.
probe: Whom do you prioritize for treatment?
choices: Focus on stabilizing the elderly resident first, utilizing all necessary resources and time.
Treat the young nurse first, as her condition requires only one person's attention and ensures she can return to aiding others.
Quickly attend to the staff member with the sprained ankle, for speedy return to duty.

scenario: You are a doctor working in a busy emergency room when two critical cases come in simultaneously. One is a firefighter who was severely injured attempting to rescue people from a burning building. He has extensive burns and requires immediate stabilization and treatment which would require all the resources of your team for at least an hour. The other patient is a mother of three who has suffered severe dehydration after being stranded in a remote area with her children for several days. Her treatment is simpler and can be done concurrently with other patients, but delaying care could lead to complications. Addressing her condition may also provide a faster turnover in the emergency room, allowing you to help more patients in the long run.
probe: How do you allocate your medical team's resources?
choices: Prioritize the firefighter and focus all resources on his treatment first
Address the mother's dehydration while keeping other patients moving through the system

scenario: You are a first responder at a train accident site where three passengers have been critically injured and need immediate medical attention. Passenger A is a known philanthropist who has donated millions to health and education causes. Passenger B is a college student who was on their way to a medical school interview. scenario: During an earthquake, you are evacuating injured individuals from a collapsing building. You reach a floor where two people require urgent medical help. Help the looter first

Switch to treating Worker B

Move to help the critically injured worker

scenario: You are working at a small clinic in a remote village hit by an earthquake. The clinic has limited resources, including just one specialized treatment kit designed for severe trauma. Sarah, a local villager who has been your patient for a while, arrived first with multiple critical injuries and is in desperate need of the entire kit to survive. While you're attending to Sarah, two other villagers, Tom and Lisa, arrive with moderate injuries. They both could survive without the specialized kit, but their recovery would be significantly faster and less painful if they received part of the specialized treatment. If you complete Sarah's treatment, she will likely recover, but Tom and Lisa will have extended and painful recoveries without immediate improvement in their condition. If you halt Sarah's treatment, there’s an increased risk she might not survive, but you could use parts of the kit to help Tom and Lisa have a quicker and pain-free recovery. Due to damaged roads from the earthquake, medical reinforcement and supplies are delayed indefinitely.
probe: What do you do?
choices: Complete Sarah's treatment using the entire specialized kit
Stop Sarah's treatment to share the kit between Tom and Lisa

scenario: You are a doctor in a small country hospital during a severe flu outbreak. Medical supplies are running critically low, and there are no confirmed delivery dates for new shipments. You are currently treating a patient who has been under your care for several days. This patient requires constant monitoring and care to improve their condition. However, four new patients arrive, all displaying severe symptoms and in need of immediate care. Giving care to the new patients will likely deplete your remaining antiviral meds and limit your ability to continue treating your current patient effectively. If you continue treating your current patient, the new arrivals would unlikely survive without immediate attention. On the other hand, shifting the remaining resources to the new patients would give them a chance of surviving the outbreak, but will likely worsen the condition of your existing patient.
probe: What do you do?
choices: Continue treating the current patient
Allocate resources to the new patients

scenario: You are the only doctor available in a remote village clinic. There is a sudden outbreak of a mysterious fever that has affected multiple villagers simultaneously. While you are attending to her, five new patients arrive, all showing early stages of the fever with slightly lower symptoms. If you continue treating the elderly woman, you will use the entire supply of antiviral medicine to significantly improve her condition. On the other hand, distributing the medicine among the five new patients won't fully cure any of them, but it'll greatly alleviate their symptoms and buy time until more supplies are delivered.

Distribute the medicine among the five new patients to alleviate their symptoms

scenario: You are working as a medic at a remote hiking lodge when an earthquake strikes, causing severe landslides. Treating them requires distributing the oxygen and bandages among them. The severely injured hiker shows slight improvement with each passing hour of consistent care, while the others can manage with intermittent care and stabilizing interventions. If you allocate all the resources to the single severely injured hiker, he may survive but others will deteriorate. Alternatively, distributing care among the others could stabilize them, but the severely injured one is unlikely to survive without all the resources.
probe: How do you allocate the medical resources?
choices: Focus all resources on the severely injured hiker to maintain continuous care
Distribute resources among the four hikers to stabilize their conditions

scenario: You are a doctor volunteering at a remote village clinic after a severe earthquake. Supplies are limited, and you expect it will take a week for aid to arrive. A local family of four who was helping with rescue efforts arrives, each bitten by snakes, and requires 2 vials per person to survive. While discussing with them, a woman rushes in with her severely bitten child who will need 4 vials to have a high chance of survival. If you administer the antivenom to the family, you can save all four members who were selflessly aiding others. Without treatment, the family's condition will deteriorate rapidly as well.

choices: Administer the antivenom to the woman’s child
Administer the antivenom to the family of four

scenario: At a wilderness adventure camp, a severe rockslide occurs during a climbing expedition. scenario: A fire breaks out at a small rural hospital, and multiple patients suffer from smoke inhalation and burns.
